COMMENT: add comments to the data dictionary
COMMIT: sends a signal to MySQL to save all un-commited statements
DELETE: deletes records from a table (all or partial depending on potential conditions)
DESC: interpretation of the data access path (synonym of EXPLAIN)
DESCRIBE: interpretation of the data access path (synonym of EXPLAIN)
DO: executes an expression without returning any result
EXPLAIN: interpretation of the data access path
GRANT: allow users access privileges to database
HANDLER: statement provides direct access to table storage engine interfaces
HELP: The HELP statement returns online information from the MySQL Reference manual. Its proper operation requires that the help tables in the mysql database be initialized with help topic information
LOAD: The LOAD DATA INFILE statement reads rows from a text file into a table at a very high speed or LOAD XML statement reads data from an XML file into a table
RELEASE: The RELEASE SAVEPOINT statement removes the named savepoint from the set of savepoints of the current transaction. No commit or rollback occurs. It is an error if the savepoint does not exist.
REPLACE: REPLACE works exactly like INSERT, except that if an old row in the table has the same value as a new row for a PRIMARY KEY or a UNIQUE index, the old row is deleted before the new row is inserted
REVOKE: withdraw users access privileges given by using the GRANT command
ROLLBACK: restore database to original since the last COMMIT
SAVEPOINT: identify a point in a transaction to which you can later roll back
SELECT: retrieve data from the a database
SET: change values of global/session variables or transaction characteristics
SHOW: has many forms that provide information about databases, tables, columns, or status information about the server
START: marks the starting point for a transaction
TRUNCATE: remove all records from a table, including all spaces allocated for the records are removed
UPDATE: updates existing data within a table
USE: The USE db_name statement tells MySQL to use the db_name database as the default (current) database for subsequent statements.
WITH: Marks beginning of a Common Table Expression block (having 1 or multple CTEs) followed by a main query
